Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: A large gathering has assembled for a special remembrance, and no one else present is authorized to lead.
Story: My phone vibrated in my pocket just as I was about to step onto the prayer mat. I glanced at the screen—my mother’s name flashed, right on time for our weekly call. For years, I’d never missed these Sunday conversations, listening to her stories, sharing my own, and making sure she and my father felt close despite the distance. But tonight, the mosque was unusually full. A special remembrance had drawn a crowd, and as the imam, everyone looked to me to lead the prayer. There was no one else; the responsibility was mine alone. My heart pounded as I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My parents expected my voice, my presence, a simple call that meant everything to them. My congregation expected my guidance, my leadership, my unwavering attention. I stood frozen, the phone buzzing in my hand, torn between the call of my family and the call of my faith community, knowing that whichever I chose, I would be letting someone down.
